questions: What is the grace period for premium payment under the National Parivar Mediclaim Plus Policy?
What is the waiting period for pre-existing diseases (PED) to be covered?
Does this policy cover maternity expenses, and what are the conditions?
What is the waiting period for cataract surgery?
Are the medical expenses for an organ donor covered under this policy?
What is the No Claim Discount (NCD) offered in this policy?
Is there a benefit for preventive health check-ups?
How does the policy define a 'Hospital'?
What is the extent of coverage for AYUSH treatments?
Are there any sub-limits on room rent and ICU charges for Plan A?

answers: The grace period for premium payment under the National Parivar Mediclaim Plus Policy is 15 days. During this period, coverage will not be available from the due date of instalment premium till the date of receipt of premium by the Company. If the instalment premium is not paid on due date, the Policy will get cancelled. No interest will be charged if the instalment premium is paid within the stipulated grace period. The grace period means the specified period of time immediately following the premium due date during which a payment can be made to renew or continue a Policy in force without loss of continuity benefits such as waiting periods and coverage of pre-existing diseases. Coverage is not available for the period for which no premium is received. The Insured will get the accrued continuity benefit in respect of the 'Waiting Periods', 'Specific Waiting Periods' in the event of payment of premium within the stipulated grace Period. In case of instalment premium due not received within the grace period, the Policy will get cancelled. In the event of a claim, all subsequent premium instalments shall immediately become due and payable.

This policy covers maternity expenses, including medical treatment expenses traceable to childbirth (including complicated deliveries and caesarean sections incurred during Hospitalization) and expenses towards lawful medical termination of pregnancy during the Policy Period. The female Insured Person should have been continuously covered for at least 24 months before availing this benefit. The New Born Baby shall be automatically covered from birth under the Sum Insured available to the mother during the corresponding Policy Period, for up to 3 months of age. On attaining 3 months of age, the New Born Baby shall be covered only if specifically included in the Policy mid-term and requisite premium paid to the Company. Cover Maternity Expenses means; a) Medical treatment expenses traceable to childbirth (including complicated deliveries and caesarean sections incurred during Hospitalization); b) Expenses towards lawful medical termination of pregnancy during the Policy Period.

The waiting period for cataract surgery is 24 months of continuous coverage after the date of inception of the first Global Health Care Policy with Us, as per Clause 2. However, if the Insured is continuously covered without any break as defined under the applicable norms on portability stipulated by IRDAI, then the waiting period for the same would be reduced to the extent of prior coverage. Additionally, if the treatment is undergone for a listed procedure in a Preferred Provider Network (PPN) as a package, the waiting period may not apply. The conditions for this include: Continuous coverage for more than twelve months, exclusion of expenses related to treatment of any Illness within 30 days from the first Policy commencement date, waiting period of 30 days for Code-Excl03, waiting period of 24 months for Clause 2, reduction of waiting period for prior coverage, and listed procedures and Preferred Provider Network list are dynamic in nature.

Yes, medical expenses for an organ donor are covered under this policy, subject to the terms, conditions, and exclusions of the policy. The policy will pay expenses up to the limits specified in the Policy Schedule, towards organ donor's treatment for harvesting of the donated organ. The organ donor must be any person whose organ has been made available in accordance and in compliance with the local regulation and the organ donated is for the use of the Insured. Additionally, the policy requires that We have accepted an Inpatient Hospitalization claim for the Insured under In-patient Hospitalization treatment. The policy also requires compliance with THE TRANSPLANTATION OF HUMAN ORGANS (AMENDMENT) BILL, 2011. This is supported by clause ii, which states that We have accepted Your Claim under "In-patient Hospitalization Treatment" or "Day Care Procedures" section of the Policy, subject otherwise to the terms, conditions and exclusions of the Policy.

The No Claim Discount (NCD) offered in this policy is a flat 5% on the base premium for policies with a term of one year, provided claims are not reported in the expiring policy. For policies with a term exceeding one year, the NCD amount with respect to each claim-free policy year shall be aggregated and allowed on renewal, with an aggregate amount not exceeding flat 5% of the total base premium for the term of the policy.

Yes, you are entitled to an Annual Preventive Health Check-up, and we will reimburse the amount as per the limits specified in the Policy Schedule. The payment under this benefit will not reduce the base sum Insured mentioned in Policy Schedule 8. You can approach us for the arrangement of the Health Check-up. However, note that we shall not be liable for any other ancillary or peripheral costs or expenses, including transportation, accommodation, or sustenance.

A Hospital is defined as any institution established for Inpatient care and Day Care Treatment of Illness and/or injuries, registered as a Hospital with the local authorities under the Clinical Establishments (Registration and Regulation) Act, 2010, or under the enactments specified under the Schedule of Section 56(1) of the said Act, or complying with all minimum criteria: having qualified nursing staff under its employment round the clock, at least 10 Inpatient beds in towns with a population less than 10,00,000, at least 15 Inpatient beds in all other places, qualified Medical Practitioner(s) in charge round the clock, a fully equipped operation theatre of its own where surgical procedures are carried out, and maintaining daily records of patients and making these accessible to the Insurance Company's authorized personnel. The institution must be registered under the Clinical Establishments (Registration and Regulation) Act, 2010, or under the enactments specified under the Schedule of Section 56(1) of the said Act, or meet the minimum criteria for a Hospital.

AYUSH treatments are covered in AYUSH Hospitals that meet the following criteria: a Central or State Government AYUSH Hospital; or b Teaching hospital attached to AYUSH College recognized by the Central Government/Central Council of Indian Medicine/Central Council for Homeopathy; or c AYUSH Hospital, standalone or co-located with in-patient healthcare facility of any recognized system of medicine, registered with the local authorities, with at least 5 in-patient beds, having qualified AYUSH Medical Practitioner in charge round the clock, and having dedicated AYUSH therapy sections as required. Relapse within 45 days from the date of last consultation is considered as continuous Period of Illness. An AYUSH Hospital is a healthcare facility wherein medical/surgical/para-surgical treatment procedures and interventions are carried out by AYUSH Medical Practitioner(s) comprising of any of the following: a Central or State Government AYUSH Hospital; or b Teaching Hospital attached to AYUSH College recognized by the Central Government/Central Council of Indian Medicine/Central Council for Homeopathy.

For Plan A, there are sub-limits on room rent and ICU charges. Room rent and boarding expenses are limited to a Single Private Air Conditioned Room. ICU charges are payable up to actual expenses provided by the Hospital. There are no specific percentages or amounts mentioned for sub-limits on room rent and ICU charges. However, the total Sum Insured payable under all covers will not exceed the In-patient Hospitalization Treatment Limits, which is not specified. The Insured has to stay in a Hospital for more than 24 hours for a covered event, the Insured is admitted in ICU, the ICU expenses are verified and certified by a Medical Practitioner, and the ICU charges are actual expenses provided by the Hospital.
